questions.text: Which of the following best describes a mechanism involved in epigenetic changes that lead to heterochromatin formation?

choices.text: Histone acetylation and DNA methylation of adenine residues
Histone deacetylation and methylation in CG islands

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Histone deacetylation and methylation in CG islands

 

Explanation: Epigenetic changes that lead to heterochromatin formation are primarily driven by histone deacetylation and methylation of cytidine residues in CG islands.

 

Epigenetic changes involve stable alterations in gene expression that do not involve changes in the nucleotide sequence.

 

Epigenetic Modifications:

  • DNA Methylation:
    • Represses gene expression by methylation of CpG islands.
    • Involved in ageing, cancer, genomic imprinting, X chromosome inactivation, and dysregulation linked to diseases like Fragile X syndrome.
  • Histone Methylation:
    • Suppress or activate transcription depending on the location of methyl groups.
    • Methylation of lysine and arginine residues on histones.
  • Histone Acetylation:
    • Activates transcription (Option A)
    • The addition of acetyl groups neutralises histone charges, relaxing DNA coiling.
    • Generally increases gene expression; affects processes like thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • Histone Deacetylation:
    • Represses transcription.
    • Removal of acetyl groups tightens DNA coiling.
    • Typically, it decreases gene expression and is linked to diseases such as Huntington's disease.

DNA replication and Histone phosphorylation( Option C & D):Not associated with Epigenetic modification.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about the lac operon is/are correct?


	Lac I is constitutively expressed.
	Lac Y is responsible for lactose transport into the cell.
	The structural genes are expressed when the CAP site is free.
	The ZYA genes are expressed when the operator site is free.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 2, and 4

Explanation:

The structural genes are expressed when the CAP site is Occupied.

 

Lac Operon:

  • The lac operon enables E. coli to metabolise lactose by producing enzymes necessary for lactose uptake and breakdown in the absence of glucose.

 

Components:

Structural Genes:

  • lacZ: Encodes β-galactosidase (Breaks down lactose into glucose and galactose)
  • lacY: Encodes lactose permease ( Helps lactose enter the cell) (Statement 2)
  • lacA: Encodes thiogalactoside transacetylase

 

Regulatory Elements:

  • lacI Gene: Encodes the LacI repressor, which binds to the operator to block transcription when lactose is absent. (Lactose unbinds repressor from Operator site)
    • Constitutively Expressed (Statement 1)
  • Promoter (P): The binding site for RNA polymerase, which initiates transcription of the lac genes.
  • Operator (O): A DNA sequence that the lac repressor protein binds to, blocking transcription when lactose is absent.
  • CAP (Catabolite Activator Protein): Bind to the CAP binding site near the promoter and enhance transcription (Statement 3). This requires requires cAMP

(Glucose inhibits Adenylate cyclase which converts ATP to cAMP)

 

Mechanism: Lactose unbinds repressor from Operator site ➜ Operator site becomes free ➜ Increases Transcription (Statement 4)

questions.text:
In their CRISPR-Cas9 experiment with a mammalian cell line, the research team observes the repair of DNA double-strand breaks. Which repair mechanisms are they most likely observing?


	Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ)
	Homologous End Joining (HEJ)
	Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)
	Base Excision Repair (BER)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1 and 2

Explanation:

In a CRISPR-Cas9 experiment, the Cas9 enzyme introduces double-strand breaks (DSBs) in DNA. The cell then uses two primary repair mechanisms for these DSBs:

  • Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ):
    A quick, error-prone repair mechanism that directly ligates the broken DNA ends without a template. Commonly results in insertions or deletions (indels), making it useful for gene knockouts.

  • Homologous Recombination / Homologous End Joining (HEJ):
    A high-fidelity repair mechanism that uses a homologous DNA template (often supplied by the experimenter) to repair the break accurately. Used in gene knock-in strategies.

DNA Repair Mechanisms in CRISPR Context

Mechanism Role in CRISPR Repair DNA Damage Type Handled
Non-Homologous End Joining Yes Double-strand breaks (DSBs)
Homologous End Joining (HR) Yes Double-strand breaks (DSBs)
Nucleotide Excision Repair No Bulky lesions (e.g. UV damage)
Base Excision Repair No

Small base damage or single-strand breaks

 

1, 2, 3 (NHEJ, HEJ, NER) (Option B):
Incorrect because NER does not participate in double-strand break repair.

1 and 4 (NHEJ and BER) (Option C):
Incorrect because BER handles single-strand lesions, not DSBs.

All of the above (Option D):
Incorrect because NER and BER are not involved in repairing Cas9-induced DSBs.

questions.text: Which of the following is the feature of the ‘M’ phase in the image of the Cell cycle?

choices.text: DNA replication occurs to duplicate the genome.
Chromosomes are highly condensed to facilitate segregation.
Cell growth and preparation for DNA synthesis take place.
Proofreading and repair of DNA replication errors are conducted.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chromosomes are highly condensed to facilitate segregation.

Explanation:

This is a key feature of the M phase, where chromosomes become highly condensed to ensure proper segregation during mitosis . They are compressed to about 8000 fold during metaphase in M-Phase.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with a family history of progressive muscle weakness, cognitive decline, and involuntary movements. Genetic testing reveals a specific type of microsatellite instability disorder. Which of the following trinucleotide repeat sequences is most likely associated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) CAG

Explanation:

The clinical presentation is consistent with Huntington's Disease, which is characterised by progressive muscle weakness, cognitive decline, and involuntary movements (chorea). The specific trinucleotide repeat expansion associated with this condition is CAG.

 

Microsatellite instability (MSI) Disorders:

  • Genetic conditions are characterised by the accumulation of mutations in microsatellite regions of DNA due to failure in the DNA mismatch repair system.
  • Anticipation is seen (Disease severity increases in successive generations)

 

Trinucleotide Repeat Sequences and Associated Disorders:

Trinucleotide repeat sequences are short DNA sequences in which a specific set of three nucleotides is repeated multiple times in tandem beyond a normal range, resulting in instability and dysfunction.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with frequent falls, difficulty climbing stairs, and an unusual way of getting up from the floor. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in a gene associated with a severe muscle disorder. Which of the following statements about the involved gene is true?

choices.text: Associated with a condition that primarily affects females
The Gene’s product is a component of the sarcomere.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Largest in the human genome

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation with frequent falls, difficulty climbing stairs and unusual way of getting up (Gower sign) points towards Duchenne muscular Dystrophy.
  • Inherited in X-linked Recessive pattern - Primarily affects males (Option C).
  • The gene affected is Dystrophin, which is the largest gene in the human genome, located on the X chromosome (Option A).
  • Dystrophin is a crucial protein found in muscle cells that helps maintain the muscle fibre's structural integrity. It acts as a bridge between sarcolemma and the internal cytoskeleton, which helps in stabilization.

 

Option D: Dystrophin is not a component of the sarcomere but is crucial for anchoring the cytoskeleton to the muscle cell membrane. Sarcomere components involved in contraction include actin and myosin.

questions.text: Satellite DNA has various applications due to its unique repetitive sequences. Which of the following is not an application of satellite DNA?

choices.text: Determining genetic susceptibility to cardiovascular diseases
Studying evolutionary relationships and genetic diversity

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Determining genetic susceptibility to cardiovascular diseases

Explanation:

Satellite DNA is not used to identify susceptibility to cardiovascular diseases, as it mainly provides information about repetitive DNA sequences rather than disease susceptibility.

 

Satellite DNA refers to repetitive DNA sequences that are found in specific regions of the genome, notably in centromeric and telomeric regions.

  • Types:
    • Highly Repetitive Sequences (HRS): These sequences repeats >1,000,000 times.
    • Simple Sequence Repeats (SSR): Also known as microsatellites, these are short, repetitive sequences.
    • Minisatellite Repeats: Known as Variable Number Tandem Repeats (VNTR), these are longer repetitive sequences compared to microsatellites.
  • Applications:
    • Forensic Identification (Option A ruled out): Satellite DNA is used in forensic science to identify individuals due to its high variability between people uniquely.
    • Paternal Dispute Resolution (Option C ruled out): It helps resolve paternal disputes by matching genetic profiles through repetitive DNA sequences.
    • Genetic Studies: To study evolutionary relationships and genetic diversity among different species. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not accurate regarding post-transcriptional modifications of eukaryotic RNA?

choices.text: The addition of a poly-A tail at the 3′ end.
The 5′ capping involves a 5′ to 5′ triphosphate bridge.
Methylation of the N6 position of adenine.
Introns are removed, and exons are spliced within the cytoplasm.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Introns are removed, and exons are spliced within the cytoplasm.

Explanation:

Introns are removed, and exons are spliced together in the nucleus, not the cytoplasm.

 

Post-Transcriptional Modification of Eukaryotic RNA:

  • Primary Transcript (hnRNA): Newly synthesised mRNA directly from DNA; includes both coding (exons) and non-coding (introns) regions.

  • Key Modifications:

Poly-A Tailing (3′ End)
  • Addition of a poly-A tail (20-250 nucleotides) in the nucleoplasm.
  • Protects mRNA from degradation.

5′ Capping
  • Addition of a 7-methyl guanosine cap at the 5′ end.
  • Involves a 5′ to 5′ triphosphate bridge.
  • Enhances mRNA stability and translation initiation.

Splicing
  • Introns (non-coding regions) are removed, and exons (coding regions) are joined together.
  • This splicing occurs in the nucleus and requires energy.

Methylation
  • Methylation of adenine residues and ribose 2′-hydroxyl groups.
  • Primarily occurs in the cytoplasm for tRNA and rRNA.

 

Bacterial mRNA:

  • Not subject to extensive post-transcriptional modifications.
  • Translation can begin before transcription is complete.

questions.text: In human somatic cells, which of the following statements accurately describes the chromatin and its characteristics?

choices.text: Facultative heterochromatin includes the Barr body
Euchromatin is found in centromeric regions
Heterochromatin is active and less stained

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Facultative heterochromatin includes the Barr body

Explanation:

Facultative heterochromatin includes the Barr body.

In somatic cells of females, one of the two X-chromosomes is transcriptionally active while the other is transcriptionally inactive and highly condensed, known as a Barr body.

 

Chromatin is a complex of DNA and proteins found in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells. It plays a crucial role in packaging DNA into a more compact, dense structure, allowing it to fit within the cell nucleus and regulating gene expression.

 

Types of Chromatin:

  • Euchromatin (Transcriptionally Active)
  • Heterochromatin (Transcriptionally Inactive)

questions.text: In a laboratory setting, E. coli bacteria are cultured in a medium where glucose and lactose is available. To increase the expression of the lac operon, which levels of lactose and cAMP would you expect to be present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) High lactose and high cAMP

Explanation:

 

In a laboratory setting aiming to maximise the expression of the lac operon, optimal transcription would be expected under conditions with high lactose and high cAMP.

 

Lac Operon:

  • The lac operon enables E. coli to metabolise lactose by producing enzymes necessary for lactose uptake and breakdown in the absence of glucose.

Basic components:

  • lacZ: Encodes β-galactosidase, which breaks down lactose into glucose and galactose.
  • lacY: Encodes lactose permease, which helps lactose enter the cell.
  • lacA: Encodes thiogalactoside transacetylase.
  • lacI: Encodes the LacI repressor, which binds to the operator to block transcription when lactose is not present. (Lactose unbinds repressor from Operator site)
  • CAP (Catabolite Activator Protein): Requires cAMP to bind to the CAP binding site (CRE) near the promoter and enhance transcription.

(Glucose inhibits Adenylate cyclase, which converts ATP - - - - > cAMP)

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is specifically designed to introduce specific genetic modifications, such as gene knock-ins or knock-outs, into the genome of an organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CRISPR-Cas

Explanation:

CRISPR-Cas is a genome-editing tool that can be used to introduce specific genetic modifications, including gene knock-ins (adding new genetic material) and gene knock-outs (disrupting or deleting existing genes).

 

CRISPR-Cas Mechanism:

  • Guide RNA: Directs the Cas enzyme to the specific DNA sequence.
  • Cas Enzyme: Cuts the DNA at the target location.
  • DNA Repair:
    • NHEJ (Non-Homologous End Joining): Repairs the break by directly ligating the DNA ends, often leading to gene knockout.
    • HDR (Homologous Directed Repair): Uses a template to repair the break accurately, allowing for gene knock-in.

 

FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization) is used for detecting and visualizing specific nucleic acid sequences in cells but does not modify genes (Option A).

 

Recombinant DNA Technology involves creating new DNA combinations but is not as precise as CRISPR-Cas for making specific gene knock-ins or knock-outs (Option C).

 

Comparative Genomic Hybridization (CGH) is used to detect chromosomal abnormalities and does not involve gene editing (Option D).

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about the significance of technology in the following image?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Used to study multiple gene expressions simultaneously
Not used to deciding the course of treatment
They have been completely replaced by next-generation sequencing.
Not used in proteomics and genotyping.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Used to study multiple gene expressions simultaneously

Explanation;

The given image represents Microarray Technique which can analyze thousands of genes at once facilitating multiple gene expression studies.

 

  • Microarray consist of thousands of microscopic DNA spots (probes) on a slide, used for hybridizing cDNA or cRNA samples.
  • Each spot on the microarray chip represents a specific gene, and by measuring the intensity of the signal at each spot, researchers can determine how much of each gene is expressed in the sample.
  • Microarrays are crucial for gene expression profiling and can assist in making treatment decisions by helping us to understand the pathogenesis of a disorder (Option B)
  • Types:
    • DNA Microarray
    • cDNA Microarray
    • Protein Microarray
    • Array comparative genomic hybridisation (CGH)

 

Applications of Microarray Technique:

  • Genotyping
  • Gene sequencing
  • Gene Expression Profiling: Used for cancer treatment decisions (e.g., identifying need for chemotherapy).
  • Protein Detection by monoclonal antibody or aptamer microarrays, useful in personalised medicine and Proteomics (Option D)
  • Clinical Uses: Diagnosing cancer, infectious diseases, and allergies.

 

 Microarrays are still being used alongside next-generation sequencing (Option C).

questions.text: Which of the following vectors is most suitable for cloning large DNA fragments up to 300 kb in size?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bacterial Artificial Chromosomes (BACs)

Explanation:

Vector

Size

Description

Plasmids (Option A)

Up to 10 kb
  • Plasmids are small, circular DNA molecules commonly used in recombinant DNA technology.
  • They are easy to manipulate and introduce into bacterial cells. However, they typically can only accommodate small to medium-sized DNA inserts. They are not suitable for very large DNA fragments.

Bacteriophages

(Option B)

10-20 kb
  • Bacteriophages, particularly lambda phage vectors, are used for cloning DNA fragments.
  • While larger than plasmids, they are still not suitable for very large DNA fragments of 300 kb.

Bacterial Artificial Chromosomes (BACs) (Option C)

50-250 kb
  • BACs are vectors based on the F-plasmid of E. coli.
  • They can accommodate large DNA inserts and are widely used for constructing genomic libraries.

Yeast Artificial Chromosomes (YACs) (Option D)

>500
  • YACs are vectors that can accommodate very large DNA inserts, even larger than BACs.
  • While they can certainly handle 300 kb inserts, they are more prone to chimerism and instability compared to BACs.

questions.text: Which type of blotting technique is used to detect specific RNA sequences within a sample?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Northern Blotting

DNA sequences

RNA sequences

questions.text: Which type of restriction endonuclease creates staggered cuts in the DNA, producing "sticky ends"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type II restriction enzymes

Explanation:

Restriction endonucleases are enzymes that cut DNA at specific recognition sequences.


 

Characteristic

Type I

Type II

Subunit structure

Complex (3 subunits)

Simple (1-2 subunits)

ATP requirement

Yes

No

Cleavage site

Random, far from recognition site

At or near the recognition site

Recognition sequence

Asymmetric

Usually symmetric


 

Type II Restriction Enzyme Subtypes:

Sticky End

Blunt End

Cuts both the DNA strands at two different sites.

Cuts both the strands at the same site.

Forms two complexes with overhanging ends.

Forms two complexes with blunt ends.

 

Type III restriction enzymes(Option C):

Recognise specific DNA sequences but cut at a short distance from the recognition site. They do not produce sticky ends and also require ATP.

 

Type IV restriction enzymes(Option D):

Target modified DNA, such as methylated DNA, rather than specific sequences. They do not produce sticky ends and are involved in the recognition of modified bases rather than sequence-specific cleavage.
